page.title: 03EARLY POPULATION GROWTH
page.content: The balance between{baptisms and {burials}gives little indication of population growth at this time. A survey of marriage entries, first made compulsory in 1754, allows an assessment of{literacy}to be made. In 1770 only 61.8% of marriage partners could write their name, by 1900 this had risen to 98.8%. The first accurate population figures are not available until the {first national Census}of 1801. From 1801 to 1851, the parish, which then included Blakedown, grew steadily from 621 to 935. In comparison Clent rose from 738 to 937 in the same period. The 1838{Tithe Map}shows that in the early 19th century, Upper Hagley was the major centre of population. The Old Rectory was built at the very top of Hagley Hill to allow the rector to carry out his extra duties in Romsley.
